t: Psalm 105
God’s Faithfulness to His People
Give*pn thanks to the Lord,*s call on his name; proclaim*ln his deeds among the peoples.
Sing*ln to him, sing praise to him; tell*ln about all his wondrous works!
Boast*ln in his holy name; let*ln the hearts of those who seek the Lord*s rejoice.
Seek*ln the Lord*s and his strength; seek*ln his face always.
Remember*ln the wondrous works he has done, his*ln wonders, and the judgments he has pronounced,
you*ln offspring of Abraham his servant, Jacob’s*ln descendants - his chosen ones.
He*pn is the Lord*s our God; his*ln judgments govern the whole earth.
He*ln remembers his covenant forever, the*ln promise he ordained for*ln a thousand generations—
the*ln covenant he made with Abraham, swore*ln to Isaac,
and*ln confirmed to Jacob as a decree and*ln to Israel as a permanent covenant:
“I*ln will give the land of Canaan to you as*ln your inherited portion.”
When*pn they were few in number, very*ln few indeed, and*ln resident aliens in Canaan,
wandering*ln from nation to nation and*ln from one kingdom to another,
he*ln allowed no one to oppress them; he*ln rebuked kings on their behalf:
“Do*ln not touch my anointed ones, or*ln harm my prophets.”
He*pn called down famine against the land and*ln destroyed the entire food supply.
He*ln had sent a man ahead of them — Joseph,*ln who was sold as a slave.
They*ln hurt his feet with shackles; his*ln neck was put in an iron collar.
Until*ln the time his prediction came true, the*ln word of the Lord*s tested him.
The*ln king sent for him and released him; the*ln ruler of peoples set him free.
He*ln made him master of his household, ruler*ln over all his possessions—
binding*ln his officials at will and*ln instructing his elders.
Then*pn Israel went to Egypt; Jacob*ln lived as an alien in the land of Ham.
The*ln Lord*s made his people very fruitful; he*ln made them more numerous than their foes,
whose*ln hearts he turned to hate his people and*ln to deal deceptively with his servants.
He*ln sent Moses his servant, and*ln Aaron, whom he had chosen.
They*ln performed his miraculous signs among them and*ln wonders in the land of Ham.
He*ln sent darkness, and it became dark — for*ln did they not defy his commands?
He*ln turned their water into blood and*ln caused their fish to die.
Their*ln land was overrun with frogs, even*ln in their royal chambers.
He*ln spoke, and insects came— gnats*ln throughout their country.
He*ln gave them hail for rain, and*ln lightning throughout their land.
He*ln struck their vines and fig trees and*ln shattered the trees of their territory.
He*ln spoke, and locusts came — young*ln locusts without number.
They*ln devoured all the vegetation in their land and*ln consumed the produce of their land.
He*ln struck all the firstborn in their land, all*ln their first progeny.
Then*pn he brought Israel out with silver and gold, and*ln no one among his tribes stumbled.
Egypt*ln was glad when they left, for*ln the dread of Israel had fallen on them.
He*ln spread a cloud as a covering and*ln gave a fire to light up the night.
They*ln asked, and he brought quail and*ln satisfied them with bread from heaven.
He*ln opened a rock, and water gushed out; it*ln flowed like a stream in the desert.
For*ln he remembered his holy promise to*ln Abraham his servant.
He*ln brought his people out with rejoicing, his*ln chosen ones with shouts of joy.
He*ln gave them the lands of the nations, and*ln they inherited what*ln other peoples had worked for.
All*pn this happened so*ln that they might keep his statutes and*ln obey his instructions. Hallelujah!*ln
